snippet: Long-held beliefs about allies and potential enemies have been upset as the Obama administration navigates the tumultuous events of the Arab Spring.
abstract: Washington is reassessing decades-old judgments following the Arab Spring and elections in several Middle Eastern countries; long-held assumptions about who is a friend of the United States and who is not have been upset, leaving many Americans confused; experts on the Middle East suggest that Americans should not assume that the rise of Islamists puts the United States in greater danger from terrorists.

byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick contributed reporting from Cairo.

lead_paragraph: Long-held beliefs about allies and potential enemies have been upset as the Obama administration navigates the tumultuous events of the Arab Spring.

headline.seo: Fast-Changing Arab World Is Upending U.S. Assumptions
headline.main: As Islamists Gain Influence, Washington Reassesses Who Its Friends Are
headline.print_headline: As Islamists Gain Influence, Washington Reassesses Who Its Friends Are

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
